channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Live Updates: Russia Restarts Gas Flow to Germany; Ukraine Targets Russian Positions Across South
item.description: The anxiety over whether Moscow would restart gas shipments through a key pipeline was reminder of Europe’s reliance on Russian energy. On the battlefield, Ukraine said it had struck dozens of targets across the south of the country as Washington announced additional military assistance.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mother and daughter receiving food in Marinka, on Wednesday.

item.title: A Village Retaken, and a Confidence Boost for Ukraine’s Troops
item.description: A Ukrainian brigade surprised Russian forces to score a rare success in the east and send a signal to other units that the Russians can be routed in this region, too.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall and Mauricio Lima
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times

item.title: Draghi Offers Resignation for 2nd Time
item.description: After the collapse of his national unity government, Prime Minister Mario Draghi of Italy went to the president to step down again, deepening the country’s political crisis.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mario Draghi, center, acknowledging applause in the Italian Parliament on Thursday.

item.title: In Argentina, a Battle Over Gender-Inclusive Language in Classrooms
item.description: The city of Buenos Aires blocked the use of gender-inclusive language in schools, reigniting off a debate that is reverberating across the world.
item.dc:creator: Ana Lankes
item.media:credit: Sarah Pabst for The New York Times
item.media:description: Agostina Fernández Tirra, left, and Luana Pereyra holding a sign using gender-neutral language in front of their school in Buenos Aires.

item.title: Turkish Strike in Northern Iraq Kills at Least 8 Tourists, Officials Say
item.description: The attack came in a region that Turkey targets because Kurdish militants take refuge there, in a new flaring of regional tensions.
item.dc:creator: Sangar Khaleel and Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:description: Medics transporting the body of a victim on Wednesday after Turkish airstrikes in the city of Zakho in northern Iraq’s autonomous Kurdish region.

item.title: London Shows How Unprepared Northern Cities Are for a Warmer World
item.description: As the heat wave rolled out, it left behind fears about how Northern European cities can cope with extreme weather driven by global warming.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Yui Mok/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Passengers at Euston train station in London on Wednesday. High temperatures have brought severe disruption to rail services in Britain.

item.title: As Temperatures Rise, ‘This Is a Preview.’ Will the Warning Be Heard?
item.description: Record heat and rampant fires are raising grim questions about the world’s ability to withstand a new era of climate change.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: Emergency services fought a fire yesterday in Wennington, England.

item.title: Local Chinese Officials Apologize for Entering Homes in Search of Covid Cases
item.description: Community workers in the city of Guangzhou were looking for people who had tested positive for the virus and close contacts of patients.
item.dc:creator: Amy Chang Chien
item.media:description: Covid testing in Guangzhou in May. Community workers in the city broke into homes to look for infected residents.

item.title: An An, World’s Oldest Giant Male Panda in Captivity, Dies at 35
item.description: The animal was euthanized in Hong Kong on Thursday because of his deteriorating health, a statement said.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:description: An An at Ocean Park in Hong Kong in 2020. In recent weeks, he was refusing solid foods. His diet swayed far from the daily intake of 30 pounds of bamboo that giant pandas normally eat.

item.title: Fighting a Brutal Regime With the Help of a Video Game
item.description: Opponents of the coup in Myanmar have flocked to a new online game that lets players shoot virtual soldiers while raising money for the real-life resistance.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Russia Taps Iran and Turkey as Allies Against the U.S.
item.description: A trilateral meeting of the leaders of Iran, Russia and Turkey seemed to suggest a new anti-American alliance. But there are major fissures between the countries, too.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, left; President Ebrahim Raisi of Iran, center; and President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey at the talks in Tehran on Tuesday.

item.title: Draghi Government Falls Apart, Returning Turbulent Politics to Italy
item.description: Days after he tendered his resignation, the Italian leader tried one more time to convince the country’s fractious parties to hang together. They refused.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mario Draghi of Italy addressing the lower house of Parliament on Wednesday.

item.title: Rishi Sunak and Liz Truss Will Compete to Replace Boris Johnson
item.description: The two emerged as the final candidates after five rounds of voting, and now will try to win over an electorate that had wearied of Mr. Johnson’s seemingly endless scandals.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Liz Truss, the foreign secretary, and Rishi Sunak, a former chancellor of the Exchequer, emerged as the finalists after five rounds of voting.

item.title: Ranil Wickremesinghe Elected President of Sri Lanka
item.description: Ranil Wickremesinghe, a canny political survivor with ties to the exiled former president, inherits a nation in deep crisis.
item.dc:creator: Emily Schmall and Mujib Mashal
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters in Colombo rallying against Ranil Wickremesinghe after he was elected as the new president of Sri Lanka on Wednesday.

item.title: Belgium Ratifies Prisoner-Exchange Treaty With Iran
item.description: Critics say that Belgium is giving into Iranian blackmail in order to secure the release of one of its nationals in Iran and that the treaty will put more Belgians in the country in danger.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: Protesters outside the Antwerp criminal court during the trial last year of Assadollah Assadi, an Iranian diplomat.

item.title: Monarch Butterflies Are Placed on IUCN Red List
item.description: The International Union for Conservation of Nature has placed the insects on its Red List. But scientists say the public can give them a boost.
item.dc:creator: Catrin Einhorn
item.category: International Union for Conservation of Nature
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Red List decision covers migratory monarch butterflies in North America.

item.title: The Latest Covid Surge and What it Means for the U.S.
item.description: We look at what it means for the country.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: Masked pedestrians in New York in May.

item.title: Russia resumes gas flow through key pipeline to Germany.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy
item.media:description: The Nord Stream 1 Baltic Sea pipeline in Lubmin, Germany.

item.title: Russia Restarts Gas Flow Through Key Pipeline to Germany
item.description: The suspense was another reminder of the reliance of Germany, and much of the rest of Europe, on Russian energy. European Union leaders urged members to cut natural gas use immediately.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy and Marc Santora

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: The E.U. plans to ration gas.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Russia may limit the amount of gas it sends to Germany through the Nord Stream 1 pipeline.

item.title: Russia Signals That It May Want a Bigger Chunk of Ukraine
item.description: A top Russian official said Moscow may extend its territorial claims to include not just the east of Ukraine but also parts of the south.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko and Eric Nagourney
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers watching emergency workers in the rubble of a house hit by rockets Tuesday on the outskirts of Sloviansk, in eastern Ukraine.

item.title: Reporter Says Taliban Forced Her to Publicly Retract Accurate Articles
item.description: A veteran war reporter in Afghanistan was told she would go to jail if she didn’t tweet an apology for her reporting. She has since safely left the country.
item.dc:creator: Katie Robertson
item.media:description: Lynne O’Donnell, an Australian journalist, in Afghanistan in 2009. When she returned this week, she said, the Taliban took issue with articles she had written.

item.title: Pearl Jam’s Eddie Vedder Suffers Throat Damage From Europe’s Wildfires
item.description: The band canceled a show in Vienna after Mr. Vedder sought treatment following a musical festival in Paris.
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez
item.media:description: Eddie Vedder performing with Pearl Jam in June in the Netherlands.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: Russia Expands Its Territorial Ambitions
item.description: Also, Sri Lanka elected a new leader and Britain narrowed its prime minister race to two candidates.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:description: Residents outside an aid center run by Russia in Melitopol in the Zaporizka region of Ukraine on Monday. Sergey Lavrov, Russia’s foreign minister, said on Wednesday that his country’s geographic ambitions now include both the Zaporizka and Kherson regions.

item.title: With Russian Cutoff Feared, Europeans Are Told to Curb Natural Gas Use
item.description: The European Union’s executive branch says member countries must cut consumption by 15 percent between now and the springtime to stave off a major crisis as Russia weaponizes its exports.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:description: Ursula von der Leyen, the president of the European Commision, in Brussels on Wednesday.

item.title: Ukraine’s first lady tells the U.S. Congress that ‘Russia is destroying our people.’
item.description: In a rare appearance by a foreign first spouse before Congress, Olena Zelenska asked for more weapons to defend against Russian aggression.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky, Stephanie Lai and Jim Tankersley
item.media:credit: Michael Reynolds/Agence France-Presse, via Pool/Afp Via Getty Images
item.media:description: Ukraine’s first lady, Olena Zelenska, addressed members of Congress on Wednesday.

item.title: Can Fashion Influencers Persuade Us to Consume Less? A Times Virtual Event
item.description: Join Vanessa Friedman on July 28 as she explores how popular culture and the influencer economy might shift the industry toward responsible fashion.
item.media:credit: Dolly Faibyshev for The New York Times

item.title: What to Know About Europe’s Heat Wave: Railways, Wildfires and More
item.description: Britain’s record-breaking heat has mostly abated, but fires still rage in Greece, Portugal and Spain.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor, Isabella Kwai, Euan Ward and Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: In London, forecasters said that the rest of the week was expected to more closely resemble a typical British summer.

item.title: Ukraine steps up attacks on key Russian targets in the south.
item.description: Attacks on a strategically important bridge and other Russian positions in the Kherson Province over the last two days raise a question: Is Ukraine preparing a larger counteroffensive?
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: Kherson, in southern Ukraine, has been under Russian control since the early days of the war.

item.title: Western Europe, a Climate Leader, Still Suffers From Global Warming
item.description: Yet it’s suffering badly from warming.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Firefighters spray water on a wildfire raging in the Monts d’Arree, France on Tuesday.

item.title: Virologists try to keep up with faster coronavirus evolution.
item.description: Health officials are trying to make far-reaching policy decisions, including on booster shots, based on little biological certainty of which viral variants will be dominant.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan
item.media:credit: Alisha Jucevic for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Food and Drug Administration must decide, based on rapidly shifting information, which variants to target with updated vaccines.

item.title: The Best Books to Take You Through Newfoundland
item.description: Michael Crummey, an award-winning author whose poetry and prose explore the region and its capital, St. John’s, shares book recommendations, local vocabulary and where to find a good pint.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crummey

item.title: Poetry and artillery: A reading list for war.
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.media:description: The author visiting the site of a helicopter crash she was in several years earlier, in 2014.

item.title: Heat Wave Complicates Global Energy Crisis and Climate Fight
item.description: First, Russia upended the world energy market, then searing temperatures drove up demand for energy, forcing some of the world’s largest economies to scramble to secure power for their citizens.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta and Melissa Eddy
item.media:description: Wildfires in northwest Spain as the nation suffers a major heat wave.

item.title: Japan Sea Turtle Stabbings Unlikely to Lead to Charges
item.description: Despite being endangered, green sea turtles are not protected by the country’s conservation laws. They often get tangled in nets, to the annoyance of fishermen.
item.dc:creator: Hikari Hida and Tiffany May
item.media:description: Green sea turtles that were found injured in Kumejima, Japan, last week, in a photo provided by the Sea Turtle Museum of Kumejima.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Britain sets a heat record.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg

item.title: The highest-ranked Russian in women’s tennis calls the war ‘a full-blown nightmare.’
item.dc:creator: Matt Futterman
item.media:description: As part of an interview with a Russian blogger in Barcelona, Daria Kasatkina came out as gay, and also said the war’s end was what she wanted most in life right now.

item.title: Putin Finds a New Ally in Iran, a Fellow Outcast
item.description: A three-way summit meeting in Tehran between the leaders of Russia, Iran and Turkey sent a clear signal that Vladimir Putin is pushing back against ostracism from the West.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin and Iran’s president, Ebrahim Raisi, at a news conference in Tehran on Tuesday.

item.title: A Mariupol teen wrapped in the Ukrainian flag has become a symbol of resistance.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht

item.title: Europe’s Heat Wave Breaks UK Temperature Records and Drives Wildfires
item.description: Europe is ill prepared for extreme heat fed by global warming. For the first time on record, parts of Britain hit 40 degrees Celsius — 104 Fahrenheit — as did Paris for only the third time.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Sunbathing on Tuesday in London, where residents awoke from the country’s hottest-ever night to face a day when more heat records broke.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Putin Visits Iran
item.description: Also, a banking scandal disrupts China and Spain debates a wind farm off its coast.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:description: In this image released by Russian state media, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, left, listened to President Ebrahim Raisi of Iran during a meeting in Tehran on Tuesday.

item.title: Iran warns Turkey against new incursion into northern Syria.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: The presidents of Russia, Iran and Turkey gave a joint news conference in Tehran yesterday.

item.title: Scenes of Devastation Emerge From a Fire-Ravaged Southwestern France
item.description: Two wildfires have ravaged nearly 80 square miles of forests, forcing 37,000 people to evacuate. The flames were fanned by a heat wave also feeding blazes in Greece, Portugal and Spain.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Les Flots Bleus campgrounds, famous from the French movies, burned out by wild fires at the foot of Dune of Pilat on Tuesday.

item.title: British Homes Were Built to Retain Heat. That’s Becoming a Problem.
item.description: Keeping homes cool in the country’s typically mild summers was never a priority.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor

item.title: How Penguins Beat the Heat and Went South
item.description: Scientists reconstructed some of the evolutionary steps that led penguins to quit tropical climates for the Antarctic life over millions of years.
item.dc:creator: Jack Tamisiea
item.media:description: Scientists say more than three-quarters of all penguin species that have ever lived are extinct now.

item.title: Rishi Sunak Takes Lead for Conservative Vote in Prime Minister Race
item.description: Political temperatures also rose on Tuesday as the field of candidates seeking to become Britain’s next prime minister was reduced by one.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Kemi Badenoch was eliminated from the race to succeed Prime Minister Boris Johnson after a vote on Tuesday, but her supporters will probably decide the outcome of the next round of voting.

item.title: ISIS Fighters’ Children Are Growing Up in a Desert Camp. What Will They Become?
item.description: Leaving captured men, women and children in prisons and camps run by Kurds risks seeding a new global terrorism disaster, rights groups and the U.S. military warn.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Bennie Thompson, Chairman of the Jan. 6 Panel, Tests Positive for the Coronavirus
item.description: Mr. Thompson will not join his colleagues at a scheduled prime-time hearing on Thursday, though he instructed the committee to move forward as planned.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane and Maggie Haberman
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
item.media:description: The positive test for Representative Bennie Thompson should not delay a hearing scheduled for Thursday that is expected to focus on inaction by former President Donald J. Trump during the attack on the Capitol.

item.title: Migrants in Morocco Are Sentenced in Attempt to Cross Into Spanish Enclave
item.description: Thirty-three men, part of a larger group, were given 11 months in prison after a deadly border-crossing effort.
item.dc:creator: Aida Alami
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Riot police officers cordoning off the area after migrants arrive on Spanish soil last month in Melilla, Spain.

item.title: Kharkiv Tried to Return to Normal. Russian Shelling Wouldn’t Let It.
item.description: Ukraine repelled the effort to capture its second-largest city, but the artillery attacks did not stop. Many residents who left have returned but fear that a new offensive is imminent.
item.media:description: Anti-tank barricades in the center of Kharkiv, Ukraine, last week. The city suffers an average of four or five Russian airstrikes a night, according to the regional governor.

item.title: Why the U.K. Heat Wave Isn’t Like the Summer of 1976
item.description: Nostalgic memories of a long hot spell decades ago have become part of the currency of political debate.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Sweltering in the sun in Trafalgar Square, London, in June 1976.

item.title: Firefighters In France Battle an ‘Explosive Cocktail’ of Wind and Flame
item.description: More than 2,000 firefighters are trying to contain raging wildfires that have burned nearly 80 square miles of vegetation and forced thousands to evacuate.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut and Aurelien Breeden
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Les Flots Bleus campgrounds, famous from the French movies, burned out by wild fires at the foot of Dune of Pilat on Tuesday.

item.title: Australia’s Environment in Crisis, Report Says
item.description: Climate change, habitat loss, invasive species, pollution and mining have contributed to a drastic decline in the populations of some wildlife species.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: David Maurice Smith for The New York Times
item.media:description: A farmer feeding cattle in New South Wales, Australia, during a drought in 2018. Extreme weather has had a cumulative effect on the country’s environment and wildlife, a report released Tuesday said.

item.title: Election Conspiracy Theories Have Become Central to the Republican Party
item.description: Why election conspiracy theories have become central to the Republican Party.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Mark Peterson/Redux, for The New York Times
item.media:description: Donald Trump at a rally in Southaven, Miss., in June.

item.title: Sri Lanka, Out of Fuel, Runs on Patience
item.description: The rage at the failure and corruption of a ruling elite is matched by generosity and ingenuity to prevent complete collapse and anarchy.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal, Emily Schmall, Skandha Gunasekara and Atul Loke

item.title: Outbreaks in China Prompt Lockdowns and Fears of Economic Woes
item.description: The emergence of more infectious subvariants of the coronavirus has triggered mass quarantines, including 2,000 tourists stranded in a popular beach resort town.
item.dc:creator: Amy Chang Chien
item.media:description: Covid testing in Shanghai last week.

item.title: Words of War: A Literary Lifeline for the Battlefield
item.description: Does poetry have any place in a war zone? For one correspondent, it is indispensable.
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Civilians fleeing fighting in Mosul, Iraq, in 2017.
